column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Get Music Rights
#Text=In order to use someone else 's music in a film , video , or other public presentation , you need to acquire the legal right to use the music .
#Text=If you want to use someone else ’s music in a film , video , presentation or other public context , you need to buy music rights to do so , if the music is n’t currently in the public domain .
#Text=This can be a complicated task because of the range of rights options and because most music has multiple parties with rights .
#Text=However , if you take the process one step at a time , you ’ll be able to get the rights you need .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Identifying
#Text=Who to Ask For Permission
#Text=Figure out what rights you need .
#Text=There are two different licenses you need before you can use a piece of music : the synchronization license and the master use license .
#Text=Each license confers different rights to the holder , but both are necessary to use a piece of music , for example , in a film .
#Text=The synchronization license grants the right to pair a piece of music with your visual image .
#Text=The master use license grants the right to reproduce a specific recording of the piece in your work .
#Text=Determine whether the music is in the public domain .
#Text=In the United States , any song or musical work published in or before 1922 is in the public domain .
#Text=In most other countries , music enters the public domain 70 years after the author 's death .
#Text=If a piece of music is in the public domain , no one owns the composition , so you can freely perform or record it .
#Text=Remember , although a composition is may be in the public domain , no sound recordings are public domain in the United States .
#Text=Thus , although the nursery rhyme " Baa Baa Black Sheep " dates back to 1765 , you will still need permission to use an artist 's recording of the song .
#Text=You can find a list of public domain music at http://www.pdinfo.com/public-domain-music-list.php .
#Text=Identify whose permission you need .
#Text=You need to get the synchronization license from the copyright owner .
#Text=The copyright owner is typically the publisher .
#Text=You must get the master use license from the person or entity that owns the specific recording you want to use .
#Text=This is usually the record label .
#Text=If you have a physical copy of the album , consult the liner notes to find the names of the publisher and the record label .
#Text=If the music is independently published , you may only need the artist 's permission to use the song .
#Text=There are three main performing rights organizations in the U.S. that represent publishers in the collection or royalties : ASCAP , BMI , and SESAC .
#Text=These organizations may be able to direct you to the publishers and labels from whom you will need to ask permission .
#Text=Requesting Permission
#Text=Contact the owners .
#Text=To use a recorded piece of music , you will typically need to get permission both from the owner of the composition and the owner of the recording you want to use .
#Text=You will need to request permission and possibly negotiate a price with both holders of those owners .
#Text=Once you have identified the person or entity from whom you need to request permission , call or write a letter .
#Text=Writing a letter is a more personal approach , and might be more effective if you are requesting permission to use the music for free .
#Text=You can find a sample letter requesting royalty-free music to accompany a yearbook slideshow at http://www.copyrightkids.org/letters.html .
#Text=A song may have more than one publisher .
#Text=You need each publisher 's permission .
#Text=Describe your intended use .
#Text=The owners of the music will want to know how you intend to present the music you are requesting .
#Text=Be prepared to describe your project in detail , with special attention to how the music will be presented .
#Text=If you are making a film , describe the plot .
#Text=Give an estimate of your total budget .
#Text=Disclose where , for how long , and how many times the song will be featured in the work .
#Text=Discuss where and how many times your project will be exhibited ; for example , at multiple film festivals , or merely in a classroom environment .
#Text=Negotiate the price .
#Text=The purchase price for the rights you want will depend upon your intended use .
#Text=If your intended use is charitable , or if you want to use a song by a self-publishing artist who wants more exposure , you may be able to acquire some rights for free .
#Text=Typically , the owner will set a fee based upon the song you want and your intended use , and you will have the opportunity to try to negotiate a price that fits your budget .
#Text=You may be able to negotiate a reduced fee if you are a student working on a project that will only be shown in an educational environment .
#Text=Independent filmmakers who intend to screen their projects at film festivals can often get a cheaper Festival Use License .
#Text=These licenses include a stipulation that the fees will increase if the film is sold for theatrical release or distributed in some other way that increases viewership and revenue .
#Text=Consider royalty-free options .
#Text=There are many web-based services that offer access to large libraries of music that you can license for a one-time payment .
#Text=You can select the recording you would like to use , select your intended use for the recording , pay the specified fee , and download the song. .
#Text=The following is a list sources for royalty-free music :
#Text=Epidemic Sound Music
#Text=Triple Scoop Music
#Text=Musicbed
#Text=Marmoset
#Text=SongFreedom
#Text=PremiumBeat
#Text=Vimeo.com
#Text=Atomica Music Library
#Text=AffixMusic
#Text=Jamendo Music
#Text=Warnings
#Text=This article is intended as legal information and does not provide legal advice .
#Text=If you need legal advice , contact a licensed attorney .
